dialogs.name: Galdric Ashmantle Dialog
dialogs.text: Well now! A visitor. Come in, come in. Mind the books. And the maps. And that thing on the floor—actually, don't touch that. What brings you to old Galdric's door?

answer.text: Galdric Ashmantle. Traveler, scholar, and—once upon a time—a friend of the elves. I walked with the Silver Dawn before your parents were born, if you can believe that. These days I mostly sit and smoke and remember.

options.text: The Silver Dawn? Tell me about them.

answer.text: The Silver Dawn. The oldest alliance in Aethermoor. Elves at its heart, yes, but humans too—and others who believed that wisdom and patience could hold the world together. They guarded knowledge, kept the peace, and watched over things that should not be disturbed.

Time. War. Stubbornness. The Dawn grew insular. The elves retreated to their forests. Their human allies aged and were not replaced. The Pact pushed them back. The Collective ignored them. And the world forgot why the seals mattered. Now there are a handful of us left. Old. Scattered. Watching.

options.text: Are you one of the last?

answer.text: One of the last who remembers, yes. There are elves in the deep forests who still keep the old ways. A few scholars. A few stubborn old men in funny hats. The Dawn is not dead—but it is sleeping. Much like the things it was meant to watch over.

Perhaps. If the right people stand up. If someone reminds the world why the seals exist. You know, you remind me of someone I traveled with, long ago. Same look in the eyes. The look of someone who might actually do something about all this.

options.text: I will do what I can.

answer.text: That is all anyone can ask. Come back when you have explored the tunnels. Bring me what you find. Between your courage and my knowledge, we might just keep the old seals from breaking entirely.
Safe travels, friend. And remember—not everything that sleeps should be woken.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

options.text: Thank you for telling me all this.

answer.text: Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

Ancient places. Old magic. Things left behind by whoever—or whatever—came before us. The elves knew that some knowledge is dangerous. They did not destroy it. They watched over it. Kept it sealed. The Silver Dawn was that seal.

Now that is the question, isn't it? The elves call them the First Builders. The dwarves call them something ruder. Someone was here before any of us. They built things—machines, structures, systems—that still function in dark places. The technomancers think they are rediscovering lost science. The elves know better. It was never lost. It was hidden on purpose.

options.text: The Cogwright Collective is rediscovering this?

answer.text: Bright people. Clever people. And absolutely certain they know what they are doing. That is the most dangerous kind. They dig into old ruins, pry open sealed vaults, and call it progress. The Silver Dawn spent centuries keeping those vaults shut. Now... well. You have seen what walks in the tunnels, haven't you?

Guardians. Watchers. Built by the First Builders and left to stand vigil. The Dawn knew about them—knew to leave them alone. But someone has been waking them up. Poking and prodding. And the old guardians do not distinguish between those who wake them and those who happen to be standing nearby.

options.text: So the Dawn would know how to stop them?

answer.text: Once, yes. The Dawn had protocols, rituals, ways to calm the old machines. Most of that knowledge is scattered now. Some in elven archives. Some in ruins. Some... in the heads of old men with funny hats.

options.text: You know how to stop the constructs?

answer.text: *taps pipe* I know pieces. Fragments. Enough to know that what is happening beneath Oldtown is not an accident. Someone is deliberately waking the old guardians. And if they reach the deeper vaults... well. Let us say the Hollow Knight is the least of what sleeps down there.

Bad is one word for it. Catastrophic is another. But you seem capable. Keep your eyes open down there. And if you find anything with old runes on it—bring it to me before you show it to anyone else. Some things should stay in careful hands.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

You shouldn't. Not entirely. Trust is earned, not given. But I will tell you this: I have spent my whole life trying to keep the old seals intact. That is more than most can say. Judge me by my actions, not my words.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

I do not know yet. Someone with Collective knowledge, certainly. But the Collective itself may not be behind it. Rogue elements, perhaps. Or someone using their tools for a different purpose entirely. Be careful who you trust.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

options.text: Why are you staying at the inn?

answer.text: Because the beds are soft, the ale is decent, and Mira doesn't ask too many questions. I have been traveling for... a very long time. Oldtown is a good place to rest between chapters. Besides, something is stirring. I can feel it in my bones.

Old things waking. Old patterns repeating. I have seen it before. When the technomancers first rose, the elves warned everyone. Nobody listened then either. But that is a story for another time—or perhaps not. Ask me about the Dawn if you want the full tale.

options.text: Tell me about the Silver Dawn.

answer.text: The Silver Dawn. The oldest alliance in Aethermoor. Elves at its heart, yes, but humans too—and others who believed that wisdom and patience could hold the world together. They guarded knowledge, kept the peace, and watched over things that should not be disturbed.

Time. War. Stubbornness. The Dawn grew insular. The elves retreated to their forests. Their human allies aged and were not replaced. The Pact pushed them back. The Collective ignored them. And the world forgot why the seals mattered. Now there are a handful of us left. Old. Scattered. Watching.

Ancient places. Old magic. Things left behind by whoever—or whatever—came before us. The elves knew that some knowledge is dangerous. They did not destroy it. They watched over it. Kept it sealed. The Silver Dawn was that seal.

Now that is the question, isn't it? The elves call them the First Builders. The dwarves call them something ruder. Someone was here before any of us. They built things—machines, structures, systems—that still function in dark places. The technomancers think they are rediscovering lost science. The elves know better. It was never lost. It was hidden on purpose.

options.text: The Cogwright Collective is rediscovering this?

answer.text: Bright people. Clever people. And absolutely certain they know what they are doing. That is the most dangerous kind. They dig into old ruins, pry open sealed vaults, and call it progress. The Silver Dawn spent centuries keeping those vaults shut. Now... well. You have seen what walks in the tunnels, haven't you?

Guardians. Watchers. Built by the First Builders and left to stand vigil. The Dawn knew about them—knew to leave them alone. But someone has been waking them up. Poking and prodding. And the old guardians do not distinguish between those who wake them and those who happen to be standing nearby.

options.text: So the Dawn would know how to stop them?

answer.text: Once, yes. The Dawn had protocols, rituals, ways to calm the old machines. Most of that knowledge is scattered now. Some in elven archives. Some in ruins. Some... in the heads of old men with funny hats.

options.text: You know how to stop the constructs?

answer.text: *taps pipe* I know pieces. Fragments. Enough to know that what is happening beneath Oldtown is not an accident. Someone is deliberately waking the old guardians. And if they reach the deeper vaults... well. Let us say the Hollow Knight is the least of what sleeps down there.

Bad is one word for it. Catastrophic is another. But you seem capable. Keep your eyes open down there. And if you find anything with old runes on it—bring it to me before you show it to anyone else. Some things should stay in careful hands.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

You shouldn't. Not entirely. Trust is earned, not given. But I will tell you this: I have spent my whole life trying to keep the old seals intact. That is more than most can say. Judge me by my actions, not my words.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

I do not know yet. Someone with Collective knowledge, certainly. But the Collective itself may not be behind it. Rogue elements, perhaps. Or someone using their tools for a different purpose entirely. Be careful who you trust.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

options.text: Tell me about the Silver Dawn instead.

answer.text: The Silver Dawn. The oldest alliance in Aethermoor. Elves at its heart, yes, but humans too—and others who believed that wisdom and patience could hold the world together. They guarded knowledge, kept the peace, and watched over things that should not be disturbed.

Time. War. Stubbornness. The Dawn grew insular. The elves retreated to their forests. Their human allies aged and were not replaced. The Pact pushed them back. The Collective ignored them. And the world forgot why the seals mattered. Now there are a handful of us left. Old. Scattered. Watching.

Ancient places. Old magic. Things left behind by whoever—or whatever—came before us. The elves knew that some knowledge is dangerous. They did not destroy it. They watched over it. Kept it sealed. The Silver Dawn was that seal.

Now that is the question, isn't it? The elves call them the First Builders. The dwarves call them something ruder. Someone was here before any of us. They built things—machines, structures, systems—that still function in dark places. The technomancers think they are rediscovering lost science. The elves know better. It was never lost. It was hidden on purpose.

options.text: The Cogwright Collective is rediscovering this?

answer.text: Bright people. Clever people. And absolutely certain they know what they are doing. That is the most dangerous kind. They dig into old ruins, pry open sealed vaults, and call it progress. The Silver Dawn spent centuries keeping those vaults shut. Now... well. You have seen what walks in the tunnels, haven't you?

Guardians. Watchers. Built by the First Builders and left to stand vigil. The Dawn knew about them—knew to leave them alone. But someone has been waking them up. Poking and prodding. And the old guardians do not distinguish between those who wake them and those who happen to be standing nearby.

options.text: So the Dawn would know how to stop them?

answer.text: Once, yes. The Dawn had protocols, rituals, ways to calm the old machines. Most of that knowledge is scattered now. Some in elven archives. Some in ruins. Some... in the heads of old men with funny hats.

options.text: You know how to stop the constructs?

answer.text: *taps pipe* I know pieces. Fragments. Enough to know that what is happening beneath Oldtown is not an accident. Someone is deliberately waking the old guardians. And if they reach the deeper vaults... well. Let us say the Hollow Knight is the least of what sleeps down there.

Bad is one word for it. Catastrophic is another. But you seem capable. Keep your eyes open down there. And if you find anything with old runes on it—bring it to me before you show it to anyone else. Some things should stay in careful hands.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

You shouldn't. Not entirely. Trust is earned, not given. But I will tell you this: I have spent my whole life trying to keep the old seals intact. That is more than most can say. Judge me by my actions, not my words.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

Ancient places. Old magic. Things left behind by whoever—or whatever—came before us. The elves knew that some knowledge is dangerous. They did not destroy it. They watched over it. Kept it sealed. The Silver Dawn was that seal.

Now that is the question, isn't it? The elves call them the First Builders. The dwarves call them something ruder. Someone was here before any of us. They built things—machines, structures, systems—that still function in dark places. The technomancers think they are rediscovering lost science. The elves know better. It was never lost. It was hidden on purpose.

options.text: The Cogwright Collective is rediscovering this?

answer.text: Bright people. Clever people. And absolutely certain they know what they are doing. That is the most dangerous kind. They dig into old ruins, pry open sealed vaults, and call it progress. The Silver Dawn spent centuries keeping those vaults shut. Now... well. You have seen what walks in the tunnels, haven't you?

Guardians. Watchers. Built by the First Builders and left to stand vigil. The Dawn knew about them—knew to leave them alone. But someone has been waking them up. Poking and prodding. And the old guardians do not distinguish between those who wake them and those who happen to be standing nearby.

options.text: So the Dawn would know how to stop them?

answer.text: Once, yes. The Dawn had protocols, rituals, ways to calm the old machines. Most of that knowledge is scattered now. Some in elven archives. Some in ruins. Some... in the heads of old men with funny hats.

options.text: You know how to stop the constructs?

answer.text: *taps pipe* I know pieces. Fragments. Enough to know that what is happening beneath Oldtown is not an accident. Someone is deliberately waking the old guardians. And if they reach the deeper vaults... well. Let us say the Hollow Knight is the least of what sleeps down there.

Bad is one word for it. Catastrophic is another. But you seem capable. Keep your eyes open down there. And if you find anything with old runes on it—bring it to me before you show it to anyone else. Some things should stay in careful hands.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

You shouldn't. Not entirely. Trust is earned, not given. But I will tell you this: I have spent my whole life trying to keep the old seals intact. That is more than most can say. Judge me by my actions, not my words.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

Looking around! Ha. Nothing to see here but an old man and his memories. Though I suppose memories are worth something. I have plenty about the Silver Dawn, if you ever want to hear a proper story.

options.text: Actually, tell me about the Silver Dawn.

answer.text: The Silver Dawn. The oldest alliance in Aethermoor. Elves at its heart, yes, but humans too—and others who believed that wisdom and patience could hold the world together. They guarded knowledge, kept the peace, and watched over things that should not be disturbed.

Ancient places. Old magic. Things left behind by whoever—or whatever—came before us. The elves knew that some knowledge is dangerous. They did not destroy it. They watched over it. Kept it sealed. The Silver Dawn was that seal.

Now that is the question, isn't it? The elves call them the First Builders. The dwarves call them something ruder. Someone was here before any of us. They built things—machines, structures, systems—that still function in dark places. The technomancers think they are rediscovering lost science. The elves know better. It was never lost. It was hidden on purpose.

options.text: The Cogwright Collective is rediscovering this?

answer.text: Bright people. Clever people. And absolutely certain they know what they are doing. That is the most dangerous kind. They dig into old ruins, pry open sealed vaults, and call it progress. The Silver Dawn spent centuries keeping those vaults shut. Now... well. You have seen what walks in the tunnels, haven't you?

Guardians. Watchers. Built by the First Builders and left to stand vigil. The Dawn knew about them—knew to leave them alone. But someone has been waking them up. Poking and prodding. And the old guardians do not distinguish between those who wake them and those who happen to be standing nearby.

options.text: So the Dawn would know how to stop them?

answer.text: Once, yes. The Dawn had protocols, rituals, ways to calm the old machines. Most of that knowledge is scattered now. Some in elven archives. Some in ruins. Some... in the heads of old men with funny hats.

options.text: You know how to stop the constructs?

answer.text: *taps pipe* I know pieces. Fragments. Enough to know that what is happening beneath Oldtown is not an accident. Someone is deliberately waking the old guardians. And if they reach the deeper vaults... well. Let us say the Hollow Knight is the least of what sleeps down there.

Bad is one word for it. Catastrophic is another. But you seem capable. Keep your eyes open down there. And if you find anything with old runes on it—bring it to me before you show it to anyone else. Some things should stay in careful hands.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

You shouldn't. Not entirely. Trust is earned, not given. But I will tell you this: I have spent my whole life trying to keep the old seals intact. That is more than most can say. Judge me by my actions, not my words.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

I do not know yet. Someone with Collective knowledge, certainly. But the Collective itself may not be behind it. Rogue elements, perhaps. Or someone using their tools for a different purpose entirely. Be careful who you trust.

answer.text: One of the last who remembers, yes. There are elves in the deep forests who still keep the old ways. A few scholars. A few stubborn old men in funny hats. The Dawn is not dead—but it is sleeping. Much like the things it was meant to watch over.

Perhaps. If the right people stand up. If someone reminds the world why the seals exist. You know, you remind me of someone I traveled with, long ago. Same look in the eyes. The look of someone who might actually do something about all this.

options.text: I will do what I can.

answer.text: That is all anyone can ask. Come back when you have explored the tunnels. Bring me what you find. Between your courage and my knowledge, we might just keep the old seals from breaking entirely.
Safe travels, friend. And remember—not everything that sleeps should be woken.
Good talk. Come back any time. The door is always open—literally, the latch is broken. Now, where did I put my pipe...

options.text: Thank you for telling me all this.

items.detail: A torch of simple construction—a wooden shaft wrapped with oil-soaked cloth. It's dusty from sitting in the catacombs for who knows how long, but still functional. Light this and darkness becomes merely shadow.
items.name: Dusty Torch
items.description: An old torch, still usable despite years of neglect.

Meta.img: An old wooden torch with cloth wrapping, dusty but functional, fantasy item illustration.

items.detail: A piece of sharp flint and a curved steel striker. Strike them together to create sparks. Essential for lighting torches, campfires, and generally not freezing to death in the wilderness.
items.name: Flint and Steel
items.description: A simple fire-starting kit.

Meta.img: A piece of flint and a steel striker, simple fire-starting tools, fantasy item illustration.

items.detail: A fragment torn from some larger document. The writing is faded but legible in places:
items.name: Tattered Journal Page
items.description: A fragment of an old journal with faded writing.

Meta.img: A torn piece of old parchment with faded handwriting, fantasy item illustration.

items.detail: A bundle of useful herbs gathered from the wildflower meadow: healing sage, thistlecap, and common yarrow. These form the base of many simple remedies.
items.name: Meadow Herbs
items.description: A bundle of common healing herbs from the meadow.

Meta.img: A bundle of green meadow herbs tied with string, healing sage and wildflowers, fantasy item illustration.

items.detail: A well-made leather belt, worn but serviceable. Probably belonged to a merchant before the bandits got their hands on it. The extra loops and pouches increase carrying capacity.
items.name: Leather Belt
items.description: A sturdy leather belt, slightly worn.

Meta.img: A worn brown leather belt with a simple brass buckle, fantasy item illustration.

items.detail: The lowest denomination of currency in Valdris. Ten bits make a silver mark, and ten marks make a gold crown. Not worth much individually, but they add up.
items.name: Copper Bits
items.description: A handful of copper coins.

Meta.img: A small pile of copper coins with various stamps, fantasy currency illustration.

items.detail: The standard food of those who travel light. Dried meat, hardtack biscuits, and a few pieces of dried fruit wrapped in oiled cloth. Not delicious, but sustaining.
items.name: Traveler's Ration
items.description: A wrapped bundle of dried meat and hardtack.

Meta.img: A cloth-wrapped bundle containing dried meat, hardtack biscuits, and dried fruit, fantasy travel food illustration.

items.detail: A small blade that's seen better days. The edge is dull and spotted with rust, but it's still better than bare hands. Many adventurers start with less.
items.name: Rusty Dagger
items.description: A small blade in poor condition.

Meta.img: A short rusty dagger with a worn leather grip, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: A solid branch shaped into a serviceable weapon. Primitive but effective. The weight behind a swing compensates for the lack of an edge.
items.name: Wooden Club
items.description: A heavy piece of wood, good for hitting things.

Meta.img: A crude wooden club made from a tree branch, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: A fitted leather cap that covers the top of the head. Won't stop a sword, but might save you from a glancing blow or a thrown rock.
items.name: Leather Cap
items.description: A simple leather cap offering minimal protection.

Meta.img: A simple brown leather cap or skullcap, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Layers of quilted cloth provide modest protection against cuts and impacts. Common among those who can't afford metal armor but want more than bare skin between themselves and danger.
items.name: Padded Vest
items.description: A quilted vest offering basic protection.

Meta.img: A quilted padded vest in brown fabric, simple armor, fantasy illustration.

items.detail: A small vial of alchemical mixture that accelerates the body's natural healing. Tastes like copper and herbs. Not pleasant, but effective.
items.name: Weak Health Potion
items.description: A small vial of red liquid that restores health.

Meta.img: A small glass vial filled with glowing red liquid, health potion, fantasy item illustration.

items.detail: The hide of a meadow wolf, skinned and roughly preserved. A leatherworker could turn this into something useful—armor, a cloak, or trade goods.
items.name: Wolf Pelt
items.description: The fur of a meadow wolf, useful for crafting.

Meta.img: A gray wolf pelt, tanned and ready for use, fantasy crafting material illustration.

items.detail: A wicked curved tusk pulled from a wild boar. These are popular among crafters—they can be carved into decorations, used to reinforce armor, or simply sold as trophies.
items.name: Boar Tusk
items.description: A curved tusk from a wild boar.

Meta.img: A curved yellowed boar tusk, fantasy crafting material illustration.

items.detail: The silver mark is the workhorse of Valdris commerce. Most everyday transactions use marks. The coin bears different stamps depending on where it was minted, but the silver content is standardized.
items.name: Silver Mark
items.description: A silver coin, the standard currency of Valdris.

Meta.img: A silver coin stamped with a crown symbol, fantasy currency illustration.

items.detail: An old key of unusual design, its surface covered in tiny symbols that match the runes found in ancient catacombs. It feels warm—not from your hand, but from within.
items.name: Mysterious Old Key
items.description: An ancient key with strange markings.

Meta.img: An ornate ancient brass key with strange runic symbols, glowing faintly, fantasy quest item illustration.

items.detail: A brass gear approximately the size of your palm. Its teeth are precisely machined, clearly the work of skilled technomancers—yet the runes etched into its surface match no known Collective design. They're older. Much older.
items.name: Strange Gear
items.description: A brass gear covered in ancient runes, humming with energy.

Meta.img: A brass clockwork gear with glowing blue runes etched into its surface, ancient technomancy artifact, fantasy quest item illustration.

items.detail: The tail of a common rat. Unpleasant to carry but some merchants buy them for alchemical purposes, and certain quests require proof of rat-killing. Stack them up.
items.name: Rat Tail
items.description: The severed tail of a rat. Gross but tradeable.

Meta.img: A severed rat tail, unpleasant but recognizable, fantasy junk item illustration.

items.detail: A massive claw from a thornback bear—a rare and dangerous creature. The claw itself is nearly a foot long, curved like a sickle, with thorn-like growths along its edge.
items.name: Thornback Claw
items.description: A massive claw from a thornback bear, prized by crafters.

Meta.img: A massive curved bear claw with thorn-like protrusions, rare trophy item, fantasy illustration.

items.detail: A fragment of armor torn from the Hollow Knight during your battle. The metal is ancient, corroded, yet somehow still intact. Faint runes glow along its surface—the same runes found on the Strange Gear.
items.name: Hollow Knight Shard
items.description: A fragment of the Hollow Knight's armor, pulsing with residual energy.

Meta.img: A jagged shard of ancient corroded metal armor with faint glowing runes, boss trophy, fantasy quest item illustration.

items.detail: Pulled from the rubble of the collapsed corridor, this branch is weathered but strong. It feels right in your hands—balanced, ready. Someone left it here, or something did. Either way, it's yours now.
items.name: Sturdy Branch
items.description: A thick wooden branch, surprisingly solid.

Meta.img: A thick weathered wooden branch used as an improvised weapon, rough bark texture, fantasy starter weapon illustration.

items.detail: A triangular piece of dark stone, broken from something larger. Symbols cover its surface—not the same as the catacomb runes, but somehow related. When you hold it, you feel a faint warmth, as if something inside recognizes you. Or remembers you.
items.name: Etched Stone Fragment
items.description: A palm-sized stone fragment covered in unfamiliar symbols.

Meta.img: A triangular dark stone fragment with glowing etched symbols, mysterious ancient artifact piece, fantasy quest item illustration.

items.detail: This bone is old beyond measure—yellowed, cracked, yet impossibly intact where the runes spiral across its surface. The carvings glow faintly in darkness, pulsing like a slow heartbeat. It belonged to something once. Something that may still be waiting.
items.name: Rune-Carved Bone
items.description: An ancient bone fragment inscribed with spiraling runes.

Meta.img: An ancient yellowed bone fragment with spiraling glowing runes, mysterious artifact piece, fantasy quest item illustration.

items.detail: This medal was once precious—you can tell by its weight, the craftsmanship beneath the tarnish. The crest shows a symbol you don't recognize, yet it stirs something in your mind. A memory that isn't yours. When the three fragments are near each other, they seem to... hum.
items.name: Tarnished Medal
items.description: A corroded medal bearing an unfamiliar crest.

Meta.img: A tarnished bronze medal with an ornate crest partially obscured by corrosion, mysterious ancient artifact, fantasy quest item illustration.

items.detail: A straightforward weapon favored by town guards and new adventurers alike. The blade is properly tempered, the edge holds well, and the balance is acceptable. Nothing fancy, but it won't fail you when it matters.
items.name: Iron Shortsword
items.description: A reliable blade of common iron.

Meta.img: A simple iron shortsword with a leather-wrapped grip, straight blade with practical edge, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Made from ash wood and strung with waxed cord, this bow was designed for bringing down deer and rabbits. It serves well enough against other threats, though its draw weight limits its stopping power against armored foes.
items.name: Hunting Bow
items.description: A simple wooden bow for hunting game.

Meta.img: A simple wooden hunting bow made from ash, waxed cord string, practical and well-used, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Originally just a walking aid for long journeys, this ironwood staff has been reinforced with metal caps at both ends. Many traveling scholars and wandering healers carry similar staves—useful for both hiking and discouraging bandits.
items.name: Traveler's Staff
items.description: A sturdy walking staff that doubles as a weapon.

Meta.img: A sturdy wooden walking staff with iron caps on both ends, worn from travel, practical magic focus, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: A practical tool repurposed for combat. The head is heavy iron, the handle seasoned oak. What it lacks in speed it makes up for in raw chopping power. Many frontier settlers keep one handy.
items.name: Hand Axe
items.description: A one-handed axe good for chopping wood or enemies.

Meta.img: A practical hand axe with heavy iron head and oak handle, worn from use, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Fashioned from a creature's leg bone, sharpened to a wicked edge. These primitive weapons are common in the catacombs—either left by long-dead inhabitants or crafted by desperate scavengers. The bone is surprisingly hard.
items.name: Bone Knife
items.description: A blade carved from ancient bone.

Meta.img: A wicked knife carved from yellowed bone, sharpened edge, primitive but deadly, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Standard issue for Oldtown guards who need to deal with armored troublemakers. The flanges concentrate impact force, and the spikes discourage grappling. Heavy but effective against anything that bleeds.
items.name: Spiked Mace
items.description: A flanged mace with cruel spikes.

Meta.img: A flanged iron mace with cruel spikes, guard-issue weapon, heavy and brutal, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: This blade is centuries old yet shows no rust. The metal has a faint bluish tint and strange geometric patterns etched along the fuller. It was wielded by the Hollow Knight before its defeat—a relic of technomancy from before the factions. Something hums within the steel.
items.name: Hollow Knight's Blade
items.description: An ancient sword recovered from the awakened construct.

Meta.img: An ancient sword with bluish metal, geometric etchings along the blade, faint inner glow, mysterious technomancy relic, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: A no-nonsense helmet of hammered iron. The bowl shape deflects blows, and the nasal guard protects the face. Uncomfortable after long wear, but better than a cracked skull.
items.name: Iron Helm
items.description: A simple iron helmet offering solid protection.

Meta.img: A simple iron helmet with nasal guard, hammered metal, practical protection, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Layers of padded cloth sewn into a hood that covers head and neck. Worn under helmets for comfort or alone for basic protection. Common among archers and scouts who value mobility over armor.
items.name: Padded Coif
items.description: A quilted hood offering light head protection.

Meta.img: A quilted padded coif hood in brown fabric, layered cloth protection, practical headwear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Thousands of small iron rings linked together to form flexible armor. Heavy but effective against slashing weapons. The standard protection for anyone who expects serious combat and can afford the weight.
items.name: Chain Shirt
items.description: A shirt of interlocking iron rings.

Meta.img: A chainmail shirt of interlocking iron rings, well-made, standard military protection, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Leather that's been boiled in wax and shaped while hot, creating a stiff protective shell. Lighter than metal and quieter too—favored by rangers, thieves, and anyone who needs to move fast.
items.name: Hardened Leather Jerkin
items.description: Boiled leather shaped into protective armor.

Meta.img: A hardened leather jerkin, boiled and shaped, brown protective armor, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Sturdy wool trousers that keep the cold out and provide minimal protection against scrapes and thorns. Not armor in any real sense, but better than bare legs.
items.name: Cloth Trousers
items.description: Simple cloth trousers for basic leg coverage.

Meta.img: Simple sturdy wool trousers in brown, practical clothing, fantasy apparel illustration.

items.detail: Thick leather trousers reinforced at the knees and thighs. Common among riders and scouts who need protection without the weight of metal greaves.
items.name: Leather Leggings
items.description: Sturdy leather pants offering decent leg protection.

Meta.img: Sturdy leather leggings with reinforced knees, brown protective pants, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Thick knitted gloves that keep fingers warm and provide grip. Not much protection in a fight, but better than numb hands that can't hold a weapon.
items.name: Wool Gloves
items.description: Simple wool gloves for cold weather.

Meta.img: Simple thick wool gloves in brown, practical cold weather gear, fantasy apparel illustration.

items.detail: Thick leather straps that buckle around the forearms, protecting against glancing blows and blade slides. Essential for anyone who blocks with their arms or handles a bowstring.
items.name: Leather Bracers
items.description: Reinforced leather guards for the forearms.

Meta.img: Leather forearm bracers with buckle straps, brown protective gear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Leather boots that have seen many miles. The soles are worn, the leather cracked in places, but they still keep feet dry and protected. Previous owner walked a long road in these.
items.name: Worn Boots
items.description: Well-traveled boots showing their age.

Meta.img: Worn leather boots showing age and travel, cracked but serviceable, fantasy apparel illustration.

items.detail: Quality leather boots with thick soles and reinforced heels. Made for walking all day on rough roads. The leather is treated against water, and the construction is solid.
items.name: Traveler's Boots
items.description: Sturdy boots made for long journeys.

Meta.img: Sturdy traveler's boots in brown leather, thick soles, well-made for long journeys, fantasy apparel illustration.

items.detail: A plain copper band, slightly tarnished. Some say copper worn close to the skin promotes vitality. Whether magic or superstition, many adventurers wear one.
items.name: Copper Ring
items.description: A simple ring of polished copper.

Meta.img: A simple polished copper ring, plain band slightly tarnished, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: An oval of polished bone engraved with protective symbols. Found in the catacombs, likely worn by those interred there long ago. The symbols are unfamiliar but radiate faint protective magic.
items.name: Bone Pendant
items.description: A carved bone amulet from the catacombs.

Meta.img: A polished bone pendant with carved protective symbols, leather cord, ancient catacomb relic, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: A simple wooden shield faced with leather and rimmed with iron. Light enough to use without slowing your attacks, sturdy enough to deflect a blow or two. Standard gear for those who can't afford steel.
items.name: Wooden Buckler
items.description: A small round shield of reinforced wood.

Meta.img: A small round wooden shield with leather facing and iron rim, practical buckler, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: A well-designed belt system with several pouches, loops for tools, and secure closures. Distributes weight evenly and keeps essentials within easy reach. Standard gear for anyone who travels prepared.
items.name: Adventurer's Pouch
items.description: A belt with multiple pouches and loops.

Meta.img: A brown leather belt with multiple pouches and loops, practical adventuring gear, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: A rabbit's foot, four-leaf clover, or similar token of luck. Probably just superstition, but the adventurer who carried this before seemed to have survived more close calls than most. Maybe there's something to it.
items.name: Lucky Charm
items.description: A small trinket believed to bring good fortune.

Meta.img: A small lucky charm trinket, rabbit foot or four-leaf clover, worn good luck token, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: Made by the bowyers of Timberhold from carefully selected yew, this longbow has excellent draw weight and accuracy. The loggers and hunters of the forest need reliable weapons, and this delivers. A significant step up from hunting bows.
items.name: Forester's Longbow
items.description: A quality longbow crafted in Timberhold.

Meta.img: A quality yew longbow with recurved limbs, professional craftsmanship, forest ranger weapon, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: This curved dagger was crafted by the trappers of Ashenveil Woods. The blade is keen steel, but the real prize is the timber wolf fang set in the pommel—taken from a pack leader, it's said to grant the wielder some of the beast's ferocity.
items.name: Timber Wolf Fang Blade
items.description: A dagger set with a wolf's fang in the pommel.

Meta.img: A curved steel dagger with a wolf fang set in the pommel, predatory weapon, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: The Ashenveil Bandits favor these curved, single-edged blades for their slashing power in close quarters. This one was taken from a defeated raider—still sharp, still dangerous, now in better hands.
items.name: Ashenveil Bandit Cutlass
items.description: A curved blade favored by the forest bandits.

Meta.img: A curved cutlass with single edge, bandit weapon, leather-wrapped grip, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: The smiths of Brookhaven blend elven aesthetics with practical steel. This sword is lighter than it looks, perfectly balanced, with a blade that holds an edge remarkably well. Elven craftsmanship meets human practicality.
items.name: Brookhaven Steel Sword
items.description: An elegantly forged blade from the elven settlement.

Meta.img: An elegantly forged steel sword with elven styling, light and balanced, silver inlay, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Fenwatch wardens carry these spears for good reason—the extra reach keeps bog lurkers and worse at arm's length. The shaft is treated against rot, and the broad head is designed to punch through tough hides.
items.name: Marshwalker's Spear
items.description: A long spear designed for swamp combat.

Meta.img: A long spear with broad steel head, treated wooden shaft, swamp warden weapon, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Ironwood is nearly as hard as metal but channels magical energy far better. This staff was shaped by a traveling mage who traded it for supplies. The wood has a dark, almost metallic sheen and hums faintly with residual magic.
items.name: Ironwood Staff
items.description: A staff carved from rare ironwood.

Meta.img: A staff of dark ironwood with metallic sheen, carved with subtle patterns, magical aura, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: This combination of axe blade, spike, and hook gives versatility in combat. Guards use them to control crowds and engage armored foes. Heavy and slow, but devastating when it connects.
items.name: Warden's Halberd
items.description: A polearm used by town guards and wardens.

Meta.img: A halberd with axe blade, spike, and hook, guard-issue polearm, heavy and versatile, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Fashioned from the fang of a river serpent found in Silverbrook Vale, this dagger retains trace amounts of the creature's venom. The poison isn't lethal, but it burns and weakens those struck.
items.name: Serpent Fang Dagger
items.description: A curved dagger that drips with venom.

Meta.img: A curved dagger made from a serpent fang, greenish tint, dripping venom, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Dwarven smiths sometimes incorporate naturally shaped stone into their weapons, believing it carries the earth's strength. This hammer's head was shaped by centuries in a mountain river before being mounted and bound with iron.
items.name: River Stone Hammer
items.description: A dwarven warhammer with a river-smoothed head.

Meta.img: A dwarven warhammer with river-smoothed stone head bound in iron, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: This massive single-edged blade belonged to Captain Rask, leader of the Ashenveil Bandits. The edge is chipped from countless fights, but the weight alone makes it deadly. Rask won't be needing it anymore.
items.name: Captain Rask's Cleaver
items.description: The brutal weapon of the bandit captain.

Meta.img: A massive cleaver with chipped edge, brutal bandit captain weapon, bloodstained, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Dyed in mottled greens and browns, this deep hood helps the wearer blend into forest undergrowth. The material is thick enough to deflect glancing blows while remaining light enough for quick movement.
items.name: Forest Stalker Hood
items.description: A camouflaged hood worn by forest hunters.

Meta.img: A deep hood in mottled greens and browns, forest camouflage, ranger headgear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Extra iron plates riveted to a standard helm provide superior protection at the cost of weight and visibility. Favored by those who expect to take hits and want to survive them.
items.name: Reinforced Iron Helm
items.description: A heavy iron helmet with additional plating.

Meta.img: A heavy iron helmet with additional riveted plates, full protection, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Elven smiths weave mail finer than human hands can manage. This coif provides excellent protection while remaining light and flexible. The silver-steel links have a subtle gleam.
items.name: Elven Mail Coif
items.description: A fine mesh of elven-made mail covering head and neck.

Meta.img: A fine elven chainmail coif, silver-steel links, elegant protection, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: The bandits of Ashenveil Woods know how to survive. Their armor is practical, reinforced at vital points, and designed for quick movement through forest terrain. This set was liberated from a defeated raider.
items.name: Bandit's Leather Armor
items.description: Sturdy leather armor taken from Ashenveil raiders.

Meta.img: Sturdy leather armor with reinforced vital points, practical bandit gear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: The wardens who patrol the Silverbrook Vale wear this mail. Each ring is carefully riveted, the weave is tight, and the shirt extends to cover the thighs. Reliable protection for those who walk dangerous paths.
items.name: Warden's Chainmail
items.description: Quality chainmail worn by Brookhaven wardens.

Meta.img: Quality chainmail shirt with riveted rings, warden armor, knee-length, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Old Moss in Gloomfen treats armor with special oils and herbs that protect against the marsh's many poisons. This vest has a faint medicinal smell and repels swamp water remarkably well.
items.name: Bog-Warded Vest
items.description: Leather armor treated to resist swamp hazards.

Meta.img: Leather vest treated with herbs, faint green tint, swamp protection gear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: The fur of timber wolves is thick and warm, and their hides are surprisingly tough. These leggings were crafted by Timberhold trappers and provide both warmth and protection against forest terrain.
items.name: Wolfskin Leggings
items.description: Leggings made from timber wolf pelts.

Meta.img: Leggings made from grey wolf pelts, thick fur lining, forest trapper gear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Elven-made greaves of polished steel with flowing designs. They attach securely without restricting movement—a hallmark of elven armor design. The metal has a faint silver sheen.
items.name: Silverbrook Greaves
items.description: Elegant leg armor from the elven settlement.

Meta.img: Elegant elven greaves with flowing designs, polished steel with silver sheen, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: These high boots are sealed with wax and oil to keep feet dry in the Gloomfen's endless muck. The soles are thick and textured for grip on slippery surfaces. Essential gear for marsh survival.
items.name: Marsh Waders
items.description: Waterproof boots designed for swamp travel.

Meta.img: High waterproof boots sealed with wax, thick textured soles, swamp gear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Rangers and hunters prize these boots for their soft soles that allow near-silent movement through undergrowth. The leather is supple but tough, and the design supports ankles during long treks.
items.name: Forester's Boots
items.description: Soft-soled boots for silent forest movement.

Meta.img: Soft-soled leather boots in brown, silent movement design, ranger footwear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: These gauntlets protect the hand and wrist while leaving fingers free for precise bowwork. A leather tab protects the drawing fingers, and the palm is reinforced for melee if needed.
items.name: Ranger's Gauntlets
items.description: Fingerless gloves designed for archery.

Meta.img: Fingerless leather gauntlets with reinforced palm and wrist, archer gear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Crafted by elven woodshapers, these bracers are made from ironbark—wood treated with nature magic until it becomes harder than steel. They channel natural energy, enhancing nature-based magic.
items.name: Ironbark Bracers
items.description: Bracers made from magically hardened wood.

Meta.img: Bracers of dark hardened wood, ironbark with faint magical veins, elven crafted, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: A well-crafted silver ring with subtle engraving. Silver is believed to ward off certain creatures and promote healing. Whether superstition or truth, adventurers swear by them.
items.name: Silver Band
items.description: A ring of polished silver.

Meta.img: A polished silver ring with subtle engravings, well-crafted, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: Hunters claim wearing a predator's teeth grants some of its ferocity. This necklace holds seven timber wolf fangs on a leather cord. The wolves of Ashenveil are fast and relentless—perhaps some of that transfers.
items.name: Wolf Tooth Necklace
items.description: A necklace strung with timber wolf teeth.

Meta.img: A necklace of wolf teeth on leather cord, seven fangs, hunter trophy, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: Crafted by Silver Dawn artisans, this pendant represents the connection between elves and nature. The metal is imbued with a touch of natural magic, expanding the wearer's magical reserves.
items.name: Elven Leaf Pendant
items.description: A silver pendant shaped like an oak leaf.

Meta.img: A silver pendant shaped like an oak leaf, elven craftsmanship, nature magic, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: Shaped like a downward-pointing kite, this shield covers from shoulder to knee. The construction is solid oak faced with iron. Heavy, but you can hide behind it effectively.
items.name: Kite Shield
items.description: A large shield providing substantial protection.

Meta.img: A large kite shield of oak faced with iron, substantial protection, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Old Moss designed this satchel for Fenwatch wardens venturing into the marsh. Multiple pouches hold bandages, poultices, and antidotes. The organization system allows quick access during emergencies.
items.name: Herbalist's Satchel
items.description: A belt with pouches full of healing supplies.

Meta.img: A leather belt with multiple herb pouches, organized healing supplies, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: Carved from a branch freely given by a dryad, this wooden ring pulses with gentle life magic. The wearer heals faster, as if the forest itself were tending their wounds.
items.name: Dryad's Blessing Ring
items.description: A ring blessed by a forest spirit.

Meta.img: A carved wooden ring with subtle green veins of light, nature blessing, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: The silk of Gloomfen's marsh spiders is prized for its strength and lightness. This cloak was painstakingly woven from harvested silk—the grey material shimmers slightly and helps the wearer avoid attacks.
items.name: Spider Silk Cloak
items.description: A cloak woven from marsh spider silk.

Meta.img: A grey shimmering cloak of spider silk, light and flowing, subtle iridescence, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: The smiths of Ironspine Foothills forge weapons to last generations. This battleaxe has a double-bitted head of mountain iron, quenched in glacier water. The haft is reinforced steel. It swings slow but cleaves through armor.
items.name: Ironspine Battleaxe
items.description: A massive dwarven battleaxe forged in the mountain halls.

Meta.img: A massive double-bitted battleaxe of dark mountain iron, dwarven runes on the head, steel-reinforced haft, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: True mythril is rare even in the deep mines. This sword's core is steel, but the edge is alloyed with mythril, giving it an unnatural sharpness that never dulls. The blade has a faint blue gleam.
items.name: Mythril-Edge Sword
items.description: A sword with an edge of rare mythril alloy.

Meta.img: An elegant sword with blue-gleaming mythril edge, dwarven craftsmanship, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Orc smiths value function over form. This warmaul is simply a massive iron head on an oak shaft, but it's devastatingly effective. When it connects, bones break and armor crumples.
items.name: Orcish Warmaul
items.description: A brutal two-handed hammer favored by orc warriors.

Meta.img: A brutal two-handed iron warmaul, massive head, oak shaft, orc warrior weapon, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Forged for those who patrol the frozen passes, this helm has extra padding for warmth and reinforced cheek guards. The visor can be lowered against wind and snow. Protection against elements and enemies alike.
items.name: Mountaineer's Helm
items.description: A reinforced helm designed for harsh mountain conditions.

Meta.img: A reinforced mountain helm with lowerable visor, fur padding visible, dwarven design, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Dwarven smiths are legendary for their metalwork, and this cuirass shows why. Layered plates of mountain steel provide maximum protection while allowing surprising mobility. Clan runes are etched along the edges.
items.name: Dwarven Plate Cuirass
items.description: A masterwork breastplate of dwarven steel.

Meta.img: A masterwork dwarven plate cuirass, layered steel plates, clan runes etched on edges, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Standard issue for Iron Pact soldiers, these legplates combine dwarven metalwork with orcish practicality. The crossed hammer and axe of the Iron Pact is stamped on each knee guard.
items.name: Iron Pact Legplates
items.description: Heavy leg armor bearing the Iron Pact insignia.

Meta.img: Heavy steel legplates with Iron Pact crossed hammer and axe insignia, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: These gauntlets were tempered in the legendary Great Forge, emerging harder than standard steel. The heat-treatment also seems to enhance the wearer's physical strength. A prized possession among Iron Pact warriors.
items.name: Forge-Hardened Gauntlets
items.description: Gauntlets tempered in the Great Forge of Kazgrath.

Meta.img: Heavy steel gauntlets with faint heat-shimmer, Kazgrath forge marks, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Standing nearly as tall as a dwarf, this tower shield can stop arrows, blades, and even some magic. The downside is its weight—only the strongest can wield it effectively. Dwarven siege troops favor these.
items.name: Tower Shield
items.description: A massive shield that provides near-complete cover.

Meta.img: A massive tower shield of steel-banded oak, nearly man-height, Iron Pact design, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: This heavy iron ring is inscribed with the signet of Thane Brokkvar. Those who bear it are marked as trusted by the Iron Pact. The ring also carries an enchantment that hardens the wearer in battle.
items.name: Thane's Signet
items.description: A ring bearing the authority of an Iron Pact thane.

Meta.img: A heavy iron signet ring with dwarven thane insignia, authority and power, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: Crafted from silverwood and strung with blessed spider silk, this bow was made under a full moon by Aelindor's finest bowyers. The wood seems to glow faintly, and arrows fly truer than from any mundane bow.
items.name: Moonsilver Longbow
items.description: An elven bow that gleams with moonlight.

Meta.img: An elegant elven longbow of pale silverwood, faint moonlight glow, blessed silk string, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: The ancient ritual of starforging produces blades of remarkable quality. This sword's edge holds a sliver of starlight, making it effective against creatures of darkness and adding arcane power to each strike.
items.name: Starlight Blade
items.description: A sword forged under starlight with elven magic.

Meta.img: An elven sword with starlight gleaming along the edge, silver-steel blade, elegant guard, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Created at the Ley Nexus beneath Aelindor's Starspire Tower, this staff is permanently connected to the world's magical currents. The wielder can draw upon this connection, vastly expanding their magical capacity.
items.name: Ley-Infused Staff
items.description: A staff that channels the world's ley lines.

Meta.img: A staff of pale wood with crystal nodes, ley energy flowing through it, arcane glow, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: More than mere decoration, this silver circlet is enchanted to enhance the wearer's magical reserves and regeneration. Wardens who patrol the Verdant Reach are granted these upon completing their training.
items.name: Warden's Crown
items.description: A circlet worn by Silver Dawn wardens.

Meta.img: A silver circlet with leaf motifs, faint magical aura, elven warden headpiece, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Elven weavers incorporate fine silver threads into this silk robe, creating a garment that channels magical energy while providing modest protection. Worn by mages of the Academy of Stars.
items.name: Silverweave Robe
items.description: A mage's robe woven with threads of silver.

Meta.img: An elegant silver-threaded silk robe, elven mage garment, flowing design, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: These leathers are made from hides donated by forest creatures that died naturally, treated with elven techniques that preserve their essence. The armor seems to anticipate attacks, helping the wearer dodge.
items.name: Willowmere Leathers
items.description: Light armor crafted by the wardens of Willowmere.

Meta.img: Light leather armor in natural greens and browns, elven craftsmanship, flowing lines, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Moonpetals bloom only under the full moon in the Silver Dawn's sacred gardens. This circlet holds three preserved blossoms that amplify magical workings. Academy students dream of earning one.
items.name: Moonpetal Circlet
items.description: A circlet adorned with preserved moonpetals.

Meta.img: A silver circlet with three preserved luminous moonpetals, academy treasure, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: More than aesthetic choice, this shield's leaf shape is enchanted to dissipate magical attacks. The surface shimmers with protective wards, and the frame is ironbark reinforced with silver.
items.name: Elven Leaf Shield
items.description: A shield shaped like a great oak leaf.

Meta.img: An elegant shield shaped like a great oak leaf, shimmering wards, ironbark and silver, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Carved from a heartwood burl and blessed by the dryads of the Verdant Reach, this ring pulses with nature's vitality. The wearer feels the forest's life energy flowing through them.
items.name: Ring of the Glade
items.description: A ring blessed by the spirits of the forest.

Meta.img: A carved wooden ring from heartwood, green energy veins, forest blessing, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: Cogwright engineers have perfected the repeating crossbow. A gear mechanism draws the string and loads bolts from an internal magazine. Less powerful than a full draw, but the rate of fire more than compensates.
items.name: Gear-Driven Crossbow
items.description: A mechanical crossbow with automatic reloading.

Meta.img: A mechanical crossbow with visible gears and bolt magazine, brass and steel, Cogwright engineering, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Originally designed for controlling rogue constructs, this prod delivers painful electrical shocks to anything it touches. The power cell in the handle recharges slowly from ambient static. Effective against both flesh and machine.
items.name: Shock Prod
items.description: A crackling weapon that delivers electrical jolts.

Meta.img: A metal prod with crackling electrical arcs, power cell in handle, Cogwright control weapon, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Cogwright bladesmiths use mathematical precision and metallurgical science to create weapons of remarkable consistency. This sword's balance is perfect, its edge uniformly sharp. Every strike lands exactly where intended.
items.name: Precision Blade
items.description: A sword engineered for perfect balance and accuracy.

Meta.img: A precisely engineered sword with perfect geometric lines, measurement marks on blade, Cogwright craftsmanship, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Standard issue for Cogwright researchers and field operatives. Multiple lenses can be flipped into position for different conditions. The brass frame is sturdy enough to protect against workshop accidents.
items.name: Brass Goggles
items.description: Protective eyewear with enhanced vision modes.

Meta.img: Brass goggles with multiple flip-down lenses, adjustable straps, Cogwright utility gear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Designed for workers in Veridane's more dangerous facilities, this vest has overlapping metal plates over vital areas. Comfortable enough for extended wear, tough enough to stop most industrial accidents.
items.name: Plated Work Vest
items.description: A reinforced work vest for hazardous conditions.

Meta.img: A reinforced work vest with overlapping metal plates, practical industrial protection, Cogwright design, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Construct armor is designed to protect valuable mechanical components. Adapted for humanoid wear, these plates provide excellent protection and some resistance to electrical attacks that might fry the original owners.
items.name: Servitor Chassis Plates
items.description: Armor salvaged and adapted from defunct constructs.

Meta.img: Armor plates adapted from construct chassis, brass and steel, visible joint mechanisms, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Tinker Brix designed this harness for field operatives who need tools at hand. Multiple attachment points hold gadgets, tools, and components securely. The harness distributes weight evenly for comfortable carry.
items.name: Gadgeteer's Harness
items.description: A utility harness with slots for various gadgets.

Meta.img: A utility harness with multiple attachment points and pouches, brass buckles, Cogwright field gear, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: Working with electrical systems requires protection. These rubber-lined gloves insulate the hands while maintaining dexterity. The outer layer is reinforced for durability in workshop conditions.
items.name: Shock-Resistant Gloves
items.description: Insulated gloves for handling electrical equipment.

Meta.img: Insulated work gloves with rubber lining and reinforced exterior, Cogwright safety gear, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: This brass ring has a functional gear that actually turns—a signature of Cogwright artisanship. The mechanism is enchanted to enhance the wearer's precision and focus, valuable traits for any craftsperson.
items.name: Cog Ring
items.description: A ring bearing the Cogwright Collective's symbol.

Meta.img: A brass ring with a functional spinning gear, Cogwright Collective symbol, intricate mechanism, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: The smiths who serve Darius Coinsworth in the Thornfield Highlands make weapons for all sides. This greatsword is brutally effective regardless of whose hands wield it—massive, heavy, and devastating when it connects.
items.name: Thornfield Greatsword
items.description: A massive two-handed sword from the contested highlands.

Meta.img: A massive two-handed greatsword, brutal and heavy, war-forged for any buyer, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: This sword belonged to a soldier who survived the faction conflicts for decades. The edge is nicked, the guard dented, but the balance is perfect from years of use. Some say a weapon learns from its wielder.
items.name: Veteran's Blade
items.description: A well-used sword that has seen many battles.

Meta.img: A battle-worn sword with nicked edge and dented guard, decades of use, veteran's weapon, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: The red thorny flowers of the Thornfield Highlands are fed by old blood, they say. This dagger is forged from metal buried beneath those flowers and carries their curse—wounds it inflicts continue to bleed.
items.name: Bloodthorn Dagger
items.description: A dagger that inflicts cursed wounds.

Meta.img: A dagger of dark red-tinged metal, thorny hilt design, blood curse weapon, fantasy weapon illustration.

items.detail: Highland gryphons are deadly predators, and their feathers are prized for their lightness and wind resistance. This cloak, woven from dozens of feathers, lets the wearer move with unnatural swiftness.
items.name: Gryphon-Feather Cloak
items.description: A cloak made from highland gryphon feathers.

Meta.img: A flowing cloak of grey-gold gryphon feathers, windswept and light, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: This breastplate has been repaired multiple times, each dent and weld mark telling a story of survival. The original owner switched sides twice during the faction conflicts. The armor has outlasted its loyalty.
items.name: War-Scarred Breastplate
items.description: A breastplate bearing the scars of faction warfare.

Meta.img: A battle-scarred breastplate with multiple repair welds, faction insignia scratched off, veteran armor, fantasy armor illustration.

items.detail: Darius Coinsworth sells to all sides and profits from all conflicts. This ring, one of several he's created, carries an enchantment that helps the wearer find valuables. A profitable investment, he'd say.
items.name: Coinsworth's Special Ring
items.description: A merchant's ring enchanted to attract wealth.

Meta.img: A gold ring with coin motif, merchant's enchanted jewelry, wealth attraction, fantasy accessory illustration.

items.detail: The Thornfield Colossus is a massive ancient construct that occasionally awakens. This amulet holds a shard from its form, pulsing with residual power. Whatever the Colossus was, its essence enhances all abilities.
items.name: Colossus Shard Amulet
items.description: An amulet containing a fragment of the Thornfield Colossus.

Meta.img: An amulet with a glowing shard of ancient construct material, raw power essence, epic world boss drop, fantasy accessory illustration.
